perturbation.original_text: 11.6 Insurance. Each Party shall obtain and carry in full force and effect the minimum insurance requirements set forth herein. Such insurance (a) shall be primary insurance with respect to each Party's own participation under this Agreement, (b) shall be issued by a recognized insurer rated by A.M. Best "A-VII" (or its equivalent) or better, or an insurer pre- approved in writing by the other Party, and (c) shall list the other Party as an additional insured under the General Liability Policy.
perturbation.changed_text: 11.6 Insurance. Each Party shall obtain and carry insurance. Such insurance (a) shall be insurance with respect to each Party's own participation under this Agreement, (b) shall be issued by an insurer approved by the other Party, and (c) shall list the other Party as an additional insured under the General Liability Policy.
perturbation.explanation: The omission of 'minimum insurance requirements', the removal of 'primary' regarding insurance, deleting the requirement for a 'recognized insurer rated by A.M. Best "A-VII" (or its equivalent) or better' weakens the obligation to carry comprehensive insurance coverage. This change introduces a **legal contradiction** with general commercial contract law, which requires parties to maintain adequate insurance coverage to cover potential liabilities. By removing these specific requirements, the contract becomes less protective of both parties and introduces ambiguity.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General Commercial Contract Law, duty of care, and implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing.
